abstract: Marketers will be able to bid on and use trademarked names like Louis Vuitton and Prada, as they already can in the United States and Canada.
snippet: Marketers will be able to bid on and use trademarked names like Louis Vuitton and Prada, as they already can in the United States and Canada.
lead_paragraph: PARIS  The Internet giant Google said on Wednesday that it would change its search policy for most of Europe to allow advertisers to buy and use as keywords terms that have been trademarked by others.

headline.main: Google Will Sell Brand Names as Keywords in Europe
headline.print_headline: Google Will Sell Brand Names as Keywords in Europe

abstract: An agreement could lay the foundation for a system in which companies would pay to move their content faster.
snippet: An agreement could lay the foundation for a system in which companies would pay to move their content faster.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Google and Verizon, two leading players in Internet service and content, are nearing an agreement that could allow Verizon to speed some online content to Internet users more quickly if the content’s creators are willing to pay for the privilege.

headline.main: Google and Verizon Near Deal on Web Pay Tiers
headline.print_headline: Web Deal Near On Paying Up To Get Priority

abstract: Shares in Motorola rose 6 percent on Wednesday after billionaire investor Carl Icahn said he had raised his stake in the company to 9.9 percent from 8.75 percent, Reuters reported.
snippet: Shares in Motorola rose 6 percent on Wednesday after billionaire investor Carl Icahn said he had raised his stake in the company to 9.9 percent from 8.75 percent, Reuters reported.
lead_paragraph: Shares in Motorola rose 6 percent on Wednesday after the billionaire investor,  Carl C. Icahn,  said he had raised his stake in the company to 9.9 percent from 8.75 percent, Reuters reported.

headline.main: Motorola Shares Up on Icahn Stake Raise

abstract: The comments were in response to reports that Google and Verizon were near a deal for faster service.
snippet: The comments were in response to reports that Google and Verizon were near a deal for faster service.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission said Thursday that he believed it was “unacceptable” for Internet service providers to offer faster Internet transmission to content providers willing to pay higher fees.

headline.main: F.C.C. Chief Opposes Fees for Internet Priority
headline.print_headline: F.C.C. Chief Opposes Fees For Priority On the Web
